title: Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025
description: Complete analysis of Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX hiking boots including detailed review, sizing guide, features, pros and cons, and buying recommendations.

body:
Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX Review: The Ultimate Hiking Boot Guide 2025

By Trail Expert | Updated January 2025

After spending two seasons testing the Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX across various terrains from desert trails to muddy forest paths, I've discovered why this lightweight hiking boot has become a favorite among casual hikers and trail enthusiasts. While it excels in comfort and versatility, there are crucial details every buyer should know before making their purchase. Explore National Parks Store offers the best selection of outdoor gear for your adventures.

Table of Contents

Complete Overview & First Impressions Performance Analysis & Testing Key Features & Technology My Personal Experience Pros and Cons Analysis Frequently Asked Questions Final Verdict & Recommendations

Complete Overview & First Impressions

When I first unboxed my Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX boots, I was immediately struck by their surprisingly lightweight construction. At just 14 ounces per boot (size 10), these mid-cut hikers challenge traditional notions about what a waterproof hiking boot should feel like.

Quick Specifications

  • Weight: 14-16 oz (depending on size)
  • Waterproofing: Gore-Tex membrane
  • Drop: 10mm heel-to-toe
  • Price Range: $170-190
Check Current Price on Amazon

The Cross Hike Mid GTX represents Salomon's attempt to bridge the gap between trail running shoes and traditional hiking boots. This hybrid approach creates a unique footwear option that excels in specific scenarios while making compromises in others. During my extensive testing across the Pacific Northwest trails, I discovered both the strengths and limitations that every potential buyer should understand.

Important Note

The Cross Hike series includes both the original and Cross Hike 2 models. This review focuses on the latest generation, which addressed several durability concerns from the original design. For comparisons with other Salomon Cross Hike models, check our comprehensive guide.

Performance Analysis & Testing

Traction and Grip Performance

The Contagrip outsole technology proved exceptionally capable during my testing on varied terrain. The aggressive 4.5mm lug depth provided excellent bite on loose soil, gravel, and wet surfaces. However, I noticed some limitations on smooth rock surfaces, where the widely spaced lugs couldn't maintain consistent contact.

9/10
Loose Terrain
8/10
Wet Surfaces
6/10
Smooth Rock

Waterproofing and Breathability

The Gore-Tex membrane performed flawlessly during stream crossings and wet weather hiking. I tested these boots through puddles up to the ankle height and experienced zero water penetration. The breathability, while good for a waterproof boot, still showed limitations during hot summer hikes above 80°F.

Comfort and Support Assessment

This is where the Cross Hike Mid GTX truly shines and struggles simultaneously. The EnergyCell midsole provides excellent cushioning for long-distance hiking, and the seamless upper construction eliminates most pressure points. However, the ankle support is minimal despite the mid-cut design. The padded collar doesn't cinch tight enough to provide meaningful lateral support, making these boots feel more like tall hiking shoes than true boots.

Real User Reviews Summary

"Used these for 30+ miles on the PCT. Great comfort but wished for more ankle support on rocky sections." - REI Customer Review

"Perfect for fast-paced day hikes. Lightweight feel doesn't sacrifice waterproofing." - Amazon Verified Purchase

"Quicklace system is convenient but tends to loosen during long hikes. Otherwise excellent boots." - Hiking Reddit Community

Key Features & Technology

Gore-Tex Technology

The waterproof-breathable membrane creates an effective barrier against moisture while allowing perspiration to escape. During my testing, this system maintained dry feet even during 8-hour hikes in persistent drizzle.

  • • 100% waterproof protection
  • • Enhanced breathability
  • • Durable membrane construction

Contagrip Outsole

Salomon's proprietary rubber compound offers superior grip on varied terrain. The multidirectional lug pattern provides excellent traction while self-cleaning properties prevent mud buildup.

  • • 4.5mm lug depth for aggressive grip
  • • Self-cleaning tread design
  • • Durable rubber compound

Quicklace System Analysis

The single-pull lacing system offers convenience but comes with trade-offs. While you can tighten or loosen the entire boot quickly, you lose the ability to customize fit at different foot zones. During extended hiking, I found the system tends to loosen, requiring periodic adjustments.

Sizing Consideration

Based on my testing and user feedback, the Cross Hike Mid GTX tends to run slightly large. I recommend trying them on in-store or ordering a half-size down from your typical hiking boot size. For wide feet, the standard width may feel narrow in the toe box area.

View Men's Sizes View Women's Sizes

My Personal Experience

Field Testing Results

Over six months of testing, I put these boots through diverse conditions across Washington State's Olympic Peninsula and Cascade Range. From the muddy Hoh River Trail to the rocky ascent of Mount Pilchuck, the Cross Hike Mid GTX proved both impressive and limiting in different scenarios.

Comprehensive video review of the Salomon Cross Hike 2 Mid GTX

Best Performance Scenarios

These boots excelled during fast-paced day hikes on well-maintained trails. The lightweight construction allowed me to maintain energy levels during 15+ mile days, while the Gore-Tex kept my feet dry during unexpected rain showers. The responsive midsole made scrambling over logs and small rocks feel natural and controlled.

Challenging Situations

The limitations became apparent on technical terrain and when carrying heavier packs. During a 3-day backpacking trip with a 40-pound pack, the minimal ankle support led to fatigue and occasional instability on loose terrain. The quicklace system's tendency to loosen required frequent adjustments, becoming somewhat annoying during long ascents.

Seasonal Performance Notes

Spring
Excellent for muddy trails
Summer
Can run warm in heat
Fall
Perfect for wet conditions
Winter
Limited insulation

Pro Tips from My Experience

  • • Pack gaiters for deep snow or debris-heavy trails
  • • Tighten quicklaces every 2-3 miles on long hikes
  • • Consider aftermarket insoles for better arch support
  • • Allow extra break-in time despite minimal requirements
  • • Use with merino wool socks for optimal comfort and blister prevention

Comprehensive Pros and Cons Analysis

Advantages

  • Exceptional lightweight design - At 14-16 oz, these boots feel like athletic shoes while providing boot-level protection
  • Reliable Gore-Tex waterproofing - Completely waterproof with good breathability for synthetic construction
  • Excellent traction on loose terrain - Contagrip outsole excels on dirt, gravel, and muddy surfaces
  • Comfortable out-of-box - Minimal break-in required with well-cushioned interior
  • Quick on/off convenience - Quicklace system allows rapid adjustments
  • Versatile performance - Works well for day hiking, light backpacking, and urban use

Disadvantages

  • Limited ankle support - Mid-cut design doesn't provide meaningful lateral stability
  • Quicklace system limitations - Tends to loosen during long hikes and lacks zone-specific adjustment
  • Durability concerns - Some users report premature separation at toe cap and upper joints
  • Narrow toe box - May not accommodate wider feet comfortably
  • Gap at collar - Allows debris entry due to loose ankle fit
  • Premium pricing - Higher cost compared to traditional hiking boots with similar features

Alternative Recommendations

If the Cross Hike Mid GTX doesn't match your needs, consider these alternatives from our testing:

For More Support:

Salomon Cross Hike 2 - Updated version with improved ankle collar

For Wide Feet:

Cross Hike Low models - Available in wide sizes

For Heavy Packs:

Traditional hiking boots - More robust construction

Buy on Amazon Compare Models

Frequently Asked Questions

Are Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX boots true to size?

Based on my testing and numerous user reports, these boots tend to run slightly large. I recommend ordering a half-size down from your typical hiking boot size. The boots have a generous toe box length but can feel narrow for wider feet. If you're between sizes, go with the smaller option and plan for thick hiking socks. The quicklace system allows for easy adjustment, but proper length fit is crucial for comfort during long hikes. For the most accurate fit, visit a retail store to try them on with your preferred hiking socks.

How do Cross Hike Mid GTX boots perform in winter conditions?

The Cross Hike Mid GTX boots offer limited winter performance due to their lightweight construction and lack of insulation. The Gore-Tex membrane provides excellent waterproofing for snow and slush, but temperature regulation relies entirely on your sock choice and foot warmth. I've used them successfully in temperatures down to 25°F with merino wool socks, but wouldn't recommend them for extended cold weather hiking. The ankle gap can allow snow entry, so gaiters become essential for winter use. For serious winter hiking, consider dedicated insulated boots from Salomon's winter collection.

What's the difference between Cross Hike and Cross Hike 2 models?

The Cross Hike 2 represents Salomon's response to durability and fit concerns from the original model. Key improvements include reinforced toe cap construction to address separation issues, updated heel counter for better stability, and modified collar height for improved ankle support. The outsole pattern received minor updates with extended lugs over the toe area for better climbing traction. Weight remains nearly identical, but the newer model shows better long-term durability in my testing. Both models share the same Gore-Tex waterproofing and quicklace system. For detailed comparisons, check our complete Cross Hike comparison guide.

Can you use Cross Hike Mid GTX for trail running?

Yes, the Cross Hike Mid GTX works well for trail running, especially on technical terrain where ankle protection is valuable. The lightweight construction and responsive EnergyCell midsole provide good energy return for running applications. However, the mid-cut design can feel restrictive for some runners, and the Gore-Tex membrane reduces breathability compared to non-waterproof trail runners. The aggressive Contagrip outsole excels on loose surfaces but may wear quickly on pavement. I've successfully used them for trail runs up to 10 miles, but prefer dedicated low-cut trail runners for longer running sessions. The quicklace system is particularly convenient for running applications.

How long do Cross Hike Mid GTX boots typically last?

Durability varies significantly based on usage patterns and terrain types. With regular day hiking on moderate trails, expect 300-500 miles of use before noticeable sole wear. The Gore-Tex membrane typically maintains waterproofing for 12-18 months of active use. However, some users report premature separation at stress points, particularly where the upper meets the midsole. The quicklace system components usually outlast the boot itself. For maximum lifespan, rotate with other footwear, allow proper drying between uses, and avoid extended pavement walking which accelerates outsole wear. The lightweight construction trades some durability for weight savings, so they may not last as long as heavier traditional hiking boots. Consider protective care products to extend lifespan.

Are Cross Hike Mid GTX suitable for backpacking?

The Cross Hike Mid GTX can handle light backpacking (pack weights under 30 pounds) but shows limitations with heavier loads. The minimal ankle support becomes more problematic as pack weight increases, leading to faster fatigue and potential instability on uneven terrain. The lightweight construction that makes them excellent for day hiking becomes a disadvantage when supporting additional weight over multiple days. I've successfully used them for overnight trips with ultralight packing strategies, but wouldn't recommend them for traditional backpacking loads. The comfortable midsole and waterproof protection are definite advantages, but consider more supportive options from our backpacking boot collection for serious multi-day adventures.

Final Verdict & Recommendations

8.2

Overall Rating

Excellent for specific use cases

After extensive testing across diverse terrain and conditions, the Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX emerges as a specialized tool rather than a universal hiking boot. It excels brilliantly in its intended niche – lightweight day hiking, fast-paced trail adventures, and casual outdoor activities – while showing clear limitations outside these parameters.

Best For

  • • Day hiking enthusiasts
  • • Fast-paced trail adventures
  • • Casual outdoor activities
  • • Urban outdoor exploration

Consider Carefully

  • • Light backpacking trips
  • • Technical terrain navigation
  • • Extended multi-day hiking
  • • Winter conditions

Not Recommended

  • • Heavy backpacking loads
  • • Serious mountaineering
  • • Extended winter hiking
  • • Maximum ankle support needs

Who Should Buy These Boots?

The Cross Hike Mid GTX targets hikers who prioritize speed, comfort, and versatility over maximum protection and support. If you regularly embark on 10-15 mile day hikes, enjoy fast-paced trail exploration, or need waterproof footwear that won't slow you down, these boots deliver exceptional value. They're particularly appealing to hikers transitioning from trail runners who want additional protection without traditional boot bulk.

Investment Considerations

At $170-190, these boots occupy the premium price segment without premium construction durability. The innovative design and Gore-Tex technology justify the cost for their intended use case, but buyers should understand they're paying for specialized performance rather than maximum longevity. Consider your hiking frequency and style to determine if the performance benefits align with the investment.

Where to Buy & Best Deals

For the most current pricing and availability, we recommend checking multiple retailers:

Amazon - Often best prices with fast shipping REI - Member dividends and liberal return policy

The Salomon Cross Hike Mid GTX represents innovative thinking in hiking footwear design. While not perfect for every application, it succeeds brilliantly within its intended scope. For hikers seeking the sweet spot between trail runner agility and hiking boot protection, these boots deliver a compelling solution.
